entry.title: Installs for the Scan Statistics for Network Epidemics Project

link.title: Installs for the Scan Statistics for Network Epidemics Project

entry.content:
I’m going to go from scratch, assuming you’re on Mac OS X.

Install pyenv and virtualenv

This will manage your python installations.

brew install pyenv pyenv-virtualenv

Install your desired python, which in this case is 3.7.3.

pyenv install 3.7.3

Now navigate to your directory and create a new virtualenv for this directory.

pyenv virtualenv network_analysis

For future reference:

  • pyenv stores its virtualenvs in: /.pyenv/versions/
  • pipenv stores them in: /.local/share/

Install the basics

pip install numpy ipykernel scipy matplotlib scikit-learn networkx seaborn xlrd pillow blackcellmagic joblib netwulf pycodestyle

Install basemap

Warning: large download (80MBs).

pip install git+https://github.com/matplotlib/basemap.git

Install EoN

You need to get the 1.0.9rc1 version or older, which wasn’t on PyPi.

pip install git+https://github.com/springer-math/Mathematics-of-Epidemics-on-Networks.git

Install this virtualenv as an IPython kernel in your (assumed existing) Jupyter installation

python -m ipykernel install --user --name=network_analysis

Install graph-tool on OS X with pipenv

First install it on your machine using Brew (pip is unfortunately not available here, because graph-tool is a hybrid C++/Python package).

brew install graph-tool

Now this will install graph-tool into a Python that Brew deems best. Make sure that this is the same version as the one in your virtual-env.

Next, we will want to symlink the graph-tool installation into your virtual-env installation (yes, this is awful and completely defeats the purpose of using pipenv, but these are the wonders of dev code without which life would be so much less fun :|). Use the directories here for a hint of where to go for the right directories (use pipenv –venv to find the virtual env directory).

ln -s /usr/local/Cellar/graph-tool/2.29/lib/python3.7/site-packages/graph_tool/ ~/.pyenv/versions/network_analysis/lib/python3.7/site-packages

We also need pycairo for drawing (comes with the brew installation).

ln -s /usr/local/Cellar/py3cairo/1.18.1/lib/python3.7/site-packages/cairo/ ~/.pyenv/versions/network_analysis/lib/python3.7/site-packages

entry.title: Binomial Limit to the Poisson
entry.content:
Let’s do a small test of math blogging.

A sequence of Binomial distributions Bi(n,cn)\text{Bi}(n, \frac c n)Bi(n,nc​) limits to the Poisson distribution Po(c)\text{Po}(c)Po(c) as n→∞n \to \inftyn→∞. As is often the case in probability, you can show this with generating functions. Here, however, I’ll show pointwise equivalence of the limit directly. Recall that the Binomial pmf is p(k)=(nk)pk(1−p)n−kp(k) = {n \choose k} p^k (1-p)^{n-k}p(k)=(kn​)pk(1−p)n−k and the Poisson pmf is p(k)=e−λλkk!p(k) = e^{-\lambda} \frac{\lambda^k}{k!}p(k)=e−λk!λk​.

We rely on two facts. First, that (nk)∼nkk!{n \choose k} \sim \frac{n^k}{k!}(kn​)∼k!nk​ for n≫kn \gg kn≫k, and second that if p=cnp = \frac c np=nc​, then (1−p)n−k→e−c(1-p)^{n-k} \to e^{-c}(1−p)n−k→e−c.

The first fact can be shown by a laborious Stirling’s approximation, but it is really enough to note the following1 1=nknk≥n(k)nk≥(n−k+1)knk→n→∞1. 1 = \frac{n^k}{n^k} \geq \frac{ n^{(k)} } { n^k } \geq \frac{(n-k+1)^k}{n^k} \overset{n \to \infty}{\to} 1. 1=nknk​≥nkn(k)​≥nk(n−k+1)k​→n→∞1.

The second fact follows from a definition of eee2 lim⁡n→∞(1+λn)n=eλ. \lim_{n \to \infty} \left(1 + \frac \lambda n \right)^n = e^{\lambda}. n→∞lim​(1+nλ​)n=eλ.

Encore: Deriving Stirling’s Formula

n!=∫0∞xne−xdx(Definition)=∫0∞enln⁡n−xdx(Algebra)=enln⁡nn∫0∞en(ln⁡y−y)dy(Change of Variables)∼2πne−nnenln⁡n(Laplace’s Method) \begin{aligned} n! & = \int_0^\infty x^n e^{-x} dx && \text{(Definition)} \\ &= \int_0^\infty e^{n \ln n -x} dx && \text{(Algebra)} \\ &= e^{n \ln n } n \int_0^\infty e^{n(\ln y - y)} dy && \text{(Change of Variables)} \\ &\sim \sqrt{\frac{2\pi} n} e^{-n} n e^{n \ln n} && \text{(Laplace's Method)} \end{aligned} n!​=∫0∞​xne−xdx=∫0∞​enlnn−xdx=enlnnn∫0∞​en(lny−y)dy∼n2π​​e−nnenlnn​​(Definition)(Algebra)(Change of Variables)(Laplace’s Method)​

Theorem 1: [Laplace’s Method] Suppose f(x)f(x)f(x) is twice differentiable on [a,b][a,b][a,b] and ∃!x\exists !x∃!x such that f(x0)=max⁡[a,b]f(x)f(x_0) = \max_{[a,b]} f(x)f(x0​)=max[a,b]​f(x) and f′′(x0)<0f''(x_0)<0f′′(x0​)<0, then as n→∞n \to \inftyn→∞ ∫abenf(x)dx∼enf(x0)2π−nf′′(x0) \int_a^b e^{nf(x)} dx \sim e^{nf(x_0)} \sqrt{\frac{2\pi}{-nf''(x_0)}} ∫ab​enf(x)dx∼enf(x0​)−nf′′(x0​)2π​​

Postmortem

I ran into a number of issues while transferring this post from LaTeX to Markdown:

  • I had to manually make the theorem environment
  • the \[ \] blocks had to be changed to $$ $$
  • footnotes had to be remade (also the display math environment breaks order in the footnotes)
  • align had to be renamed to aligned and wrapped in {\% katex display %}

There may be automated solutions out there. I want to explore using pandoc. Plus here are a couple other directions

  • https://www.alanshawn.com/tech/2019/10/09/latex-to-md.html
  • https://github.com/alvinwan/TexSoup
  • Panflute
  • jekyll-katex does not yet support macros.

  1. Here we use the factorial power notation n(k)≔n(n−1)…(n−(k−1))=n!(n−k)!n^{(k)} \coloneqq n (n-1) \dots (n-(k-1)) = \frac{n!}{(n-k)!}n(k):=n(n−1)…(n−(k−1))=(n−k)!n!​. ↩

  2. This can be shown by taking logs, Taylor expansion, and using the continuity of exe^xex: nlog⁡(1+λn)=n(λn+O(λn)2)→λ.n \log \left(1 + \frac \lambda n \right) = n \left( \frac \lambda n + O\left(\frac \lambda n\right)^2 \right) \to \lambda.nlog(1+nλ​)=n(nλ​+O(nλ​)2)→λ. ↩

entry.title: Customizing Embedded Images with Jekyll
entry.content:
Something I anticipate doing in blog posts is embedding images. Using the standard ![alt-text](link-to-image-asset) construction, we can do a basic embedding. However, what if we want to modify the size or the centering properties of the image?

The following instructions are based on the general information found here, but distilled for my specific usecase.

To add HTML attributes and CSS classes we should do the following ![alt-text](link-to-image-asset){:attribute="value" class="class-name"}. In the specific case of resizing an image this would be ![alt-text](link-to-image-asset){:width="400px" height="300px"}.

To add image alignment, we will have to modify our Jekyll theme with some custom CSS classes. This will vary for each theme, so check your theme’s documentation, but for the whiteglass theme, I had to make a new file main.scss in SITE-DIRECTORY/assets/ and fill it with the following:

To elaborate a little, we added the front matter, imported the standard theme CSS, and then added custom CSS classes below to define groups of properties that we can now apply to images. So to embed a centered image, for example, we would write ![alt-text](link-to-image-asset){:class="image-centered"}.

Behold!

The caption above brought to you by this method. Also alt-text is not the hover text; for hover text use the title attribute.

To add HTML attributes and CSS classes we should do the following ![alt-text](link-to-image-asset){:attribute="value" class="class-name"}. In the specific case of resizing an image this would be ![alt-text](link-to-image-asset){:width="400px" height="300px"}. To add image alignment, we will have to modify our Jekyll theme with some custom CSS classes. This will vary for each theme, so check your theme’s documentation, but for the whiteglass theme, I had to make a new file main.scss in SITE-DIRECTORY/assets/ and fill it with the following: --- --- @import "whiteglass"; .image-centered { margin: 0 auto; display: block; } .image-right { padding: 10px; float: right; } .image-left { padding: 10px; float: left; } To elaborate a little, we added the front matter, imported the standard theme CSS, and then added custom CSS classes below to define groups of properties that we can now apply to images. So to embed a centered image, for example, we would write ![alt-text](link-to-image-asset){:class="image-centered"}. Behold! The caption above brought to you by this method. Also alt-text is not the hover text; for hover text use the title attribute.

entry.title: Getting Started With Jekyll
entry.content:
So I am finally beginning to feel comfortable with the Jekyll workflow. Here I want to document all the pieces of the setup process in the case I migrate machines in the future.

I will be assuming you are on Mac OS X, though you can probably follow along on Linux by substituting apt-get in place of brew.

Install Ruby, Jekyll, and Bundler

Following the procedures here, we install Ruby

brew install ruby
echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/ruby/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

and then install Jekyll.

gem install --user-install bundler jekyll
echo "export PATH=$HOME/.gem/ruby/2.6.0/bin:$PATH" >> ~/.zshrc

Then we make a new blog

jekyll new myblog
cd myblog

Install KaTeX, Scholar, Themes, and Other Plugins

Add these lines into your Gemfile.

group :jekyll_plugins do
  gem "jekyll-feed"
  gem "jekyll-katex"
  gem "jekyll-scholar"
  gem "jekyll-whiteglass"
end

then run

bundle install

Finally, add the KaTeX CSS and Fonts to your theme. We’re going to overwrite the theme’s default headers by making a _includes folder and adding custom code to our header.html. So do the following:

mkdir _includes
cd _includes
vim header.html

and then paste in

<header class="site-header">

  <link rel="stylesheet" href="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/katex@0.11.1/dist/katex.min.css" integrity="sha384-zB1R0rpPzHqg7Kpt0Aljp8JPLqbXI3bhnPWROx27a9N0Ll6ZP/+DiW/UqRcLbRjq" crossorigin="anonymous">
  <div class="wrapper">

    <a class="site-title" href="/">Dmitry Shemetov</a>

    <nav class="site-nav">
      
        
        <a class="page-link" href="/about/">About</a>
      
        
        <a class="page-link" href="/blog/">Blog</a>
      
        
        <a class="page-link" href="https://github.com/dshemetov/">GitHub</a>
      
    </nav>

  </div>

</header>

(If you are using a different theme, find your theme’s default header file, copy it to _includes, and add the katex.min.css part.)

Finally, to use the scholar plugin create a _bibliography folder and put a references.bib in there

mkdir _bibliography

For KaTeX usage, see here, here, and here.

entry.title: Testing Jekyll, Markdown, KaTeX, and References

link.title: Testing Jekyll, Markdown, KaTeX, and References

entry.content:
Posts go in your _posts directory. Jekyll requires blog post files to be named according to the format YEAR-MONTH-DAY-title.MARKUP, where YEAR is a four-digit number, MONTH and DAY are both two-digit numbers, and MARKUP is the file extension representing the format used in the file.

Jekyll also offers powerful support for code snippets:

To link throughout the site and outside use brackets and parenthesis.

KaTeX’s display mode requires using the {\% katex display \%} tag. c=±a2+b2(1) c = \pm\sqrt{a^2 + b^2} \tag{1} c=±a2+b2​(1) Same with other environments, such as the aligned mode. 5+5=1010=5+5 \begin{aligned} 5+5 & = 10 \\ 10 & = 5+5 \end{aligned} 5+510​=10=5+5​

The katexmm tag allows you to wrap many inline instances of LaTeX without continually opening KaTeX liquid tags. Consider a function f:X→Yf: \mathcal X \to \mathcal Yf:X→Y, where X,Y\mathcal X, \mathcal YX,Y are measure spaces equipped with the measures μX,μY\mu_{\mathcal X}, \mu_{\mathcal Y}μX​,μY​.

We can also do display-type environments and use \tag to number equations lim⁡n→∞∫0π2sin⁡(x)ndx=lim⁡n→∞(2n)!!(2n+1)!!=π2.(2)\lim_{n \to \infty} \int_0^{\frac \pi 2} \sin(x)^n dx = \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{ (2n)!!}{(2n+1)!!} = \frac \pi 2. \tag{2}n→∞lim​∫02π​​sin(x)ndx=n→∞lim​(2n+1)!!(2n)!!​=2π​.(2) Unfortunately, the numbering is all manual, e.g. equation (2). Furthermore, the katexmm tag does not recognize the officially supported \[,\] LaTeX math mode delimiters. But hey, no one’s died yet, right?

Here is how we make a footnote1. We can also automatically generate references using jekyll-scholar and a BibTeX file (Shamir, 2014).

References

  1. Shamir, O. (2014). Fundamental Limits of Online and Distributed Algorithms for Statistical Learning and Estimation. NIPS Conference.

  1. We can even make footnotes in footnotes2. ↩

  2. DFW eat your heart out3. ↩

  3. This is a boomerism, the meaning of which has been lost to time but we keep using it to propagate the idealized memories of our parents. ↩
